record_data.record_plain_text: Section 1 Scope of Network Operating Agreement 1.1 This Agreement provides terms and conditions associated with technical and operational issues necessary for the implementation of Network Integration Transmission Service under the Tariff and the NITSA. In performance of their respective obligations under this Agreement, the NITSA and the Tariff, each Party shall adhere to Good Utility Practice, subject to the Agreement Limiting Liability Among Western Interconnected Systems, or its replacement, so long as both PSE and BPA are parties to such agreement. 1.2 In connection with Network Integration Transmission Service provided under the NITSA, BPA shall: (i) operate as a Balancing Authority (as defined by the NERC Reliability Standards) under applicable guidelines of NERC and WECC; or (ii) satisfy its Balancing Authority requirements, including all Ancillary Services, by contracting with PSE; or (iii) satisfy its Balancing Authority requirements, including all Ancillary Services, by providing them itself or by contracting with other entities which can satisfy those requirements in a manner that is consistent with Good Utility Practice and satisfies FERC, NERC, and WECC standards, or (iv) satisfy its Balancing Authority requirements through a combination of (i), (ii) and (iii) above. The Parties acknowledge that the Network Load referred to in this Agreement is within BPA's Balancing Authority Area (as defined by the NERC Reliability Standards) and the Network Resource referred to in this Agreement is within BPA's Balancing Authority Area.

Section 2 Definitions Unless otherwise defined herein, all capitalized terms shall have their respective meanings as set forth in the Tariff. 2.1 NERC The North American Electric Reliability Corporation, or its successor. 2.2 FERC The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, or its successor. 2.3 Tariff PSE's Open Access Transmission Tariff - FERC Electric Tariff Volume No. 7, as such may be amended or replaced from time to time. 2.4 Telemetry The sending of, or the capability of sending, real-time load monitoring data from each Point of Delivery at the interconnection site to PSE's Operating Center using RTU (SCADA) equipment for metering load, power flow, voltage and breaker status described in the Facilities Study. 2.5 WECC The Western Electricity Coordinating Council, or its successor.

NETWORK OPERATING AGREEMENT between PUGET SOUND ENERGY, INC. and BONNEVILLE POWER ADMINISTRATION This NETWORK OPERATING AGREEMENT ("Agreement") is dated as ofAugust 24, 2010 (the Date of Agreement), by and between PUGET SOUND ENERGY, INC. (PSE) and BONNEVILLE POWER ADMINISTRATION (BPA). PSE and BPA may sometimes be referred to in this Agreement in the singular as a "Party" and in the plural as "Parties." RECITALS WHEREAS, PSE provides Network Integration Transmission Service over its Transmission System under PSE's Open Access Transmission Tariff; FERC Electric Tariff Volume No. 7 (as it may be amended or replaced from time to time, the "Tariff"); and WHEREAS, PSE and BPA currently operate interconnected electric systems; and WHEREAS, PSE and the Public Utility District No. 1 of Kittitas County, Washington ("Kittitas"), have entered into an Interconnection and Operating Agreement, dated as of May 28, 2010, and to be filed with FERC contemporaneously with the filing of this Agreement, providing for the interconnection of PSE's electric system and the Kittitas electric system (such agreement, as heretofore or hereafter amended or replaced from time to time, the "Interconnection Agreement"); and WHEREAS, BPA currently purchases transmission service to serve Kittitas pursuant to the Service Agreement for Firm Point-To-Point Transmission Service under PSE's Tariff ("Point-To-Point Agreement"); and WHEREAS, with the agreement of Kittitas, BPA requested Network Integration Transmission Service from PSE for Kittitas pursuant to PSE's Tariff; and WHEREAS, PSE performed and provided to BPA and Kittitas a final System Impact Study, dated May 1, 2010, for such Network Integration Transmission Service; and WHEREAS, concurrently with the execution of this Agreement, PSE and BPA have executed a Network Integration Transmission Service Agreement (as it may be amended or replaced from time to time, the "NITSA"), under PSE's Tariff, pursuant to which PSE will provide Network Integration Transmission Service for Kittitas; and WHEREAS, PSE and BPA desire to set forth in this Agreement the operational and contractual requirements related to Network Integration Transmission Service over PSE's Transmission System for purposes of the NITSA and the Tariff. NOW, THEREFORE, the Parties agree as follows:

IN WITNESS WHEREOF, each Party has caused this Agreement to be executed in its respective names by its duly authorized representative as of the Date of Agreement. PUGET SOUND ENERGY, INC. BONNEVILLE POWER ADMINISTRATION By: /s/ John Phillips By: /s/ Robert A. Rogers John Phillips Robert A. Rogers Manager, Transmission Contracts Manager, Transfer Services Signed this 19th day of August, 2010 Signed this 24th day of August, 2010
PUGET SOUND ENERGY, INC. ORIGINAL SERVICE AGREEMENT NO. 507
Section 3 Term This Agreement shall become effective and remain effective concurrent with the term of the NITSA.

Section 9 Permits, Inspection, Metering and Communications 9.1 Permits If any equipment or facilities associated with any point of interconnection and belonging to a Party are, or are to be, located on the property of the other Party, a permit to install, test, maintain, inspect, replace, repair, and operate such equipment and facilities during the term of this Agreement and to remove such equipment and facilities at the expiration of the term of this Agreement (together with the right of entry to said property at all reasonable times during the term of this Agreement to carry out the activities pursuant to such permit) is hereby granted to the other Party. 9.2 Inspection (a) During the term of this Agreement, each Party ("First Party") shall, upon receipt of reasonable prior notice from the other Party ("Second Party") specifying the date and time of the visit, provide access for the Second Party's representatives to the facilities of the First Party as may be reasonably necessary for such Second Party's performance of its obligations under this Agreement. The Second Party shall cause its representatives to observe during any such visit all of the First Party's safety and security procedures or requirements of which the Second Party is then notified. (b) Any observation, verification, review, approval, consent, advice, recommendation, authorization, notice, inspection, test or other act by either Party ("Inspecting Party") under this Agreement shall not constitute or be interpreted or construed as, or be relied upon or held out by the other Party or by any other person or entity as, any warranty, representation or endorsement by the Inspecting Party. 9.3 Metering Equipment BPA shall be responsible for all costs associated with the purchase, installation, operation, maintenance, repair and replacement (and any necessary upgrades) of all metering equipment necessary to provide Network Integration Transmission Service under the NITSA, and BPA shall provide PSE with access to such equipment. All metering equipment and data of BPA shall conform to Good Utility Practice. The Parties shall review the metering equipment prior to its installation to ensure conformance with such standards or practices. 9.4 Replacement Metering Equipment (a) Installation of replacement metering equipment as described in the Facilities Study shall be performed by the Party installing such metering equipment. Any such metering equipment shall be owned, operated, and maintained by the Party installing such metering equipment. (b) Each Party shall permit the other Party to install, or cause to be installed, metering equipment reasonably acceptable to PSE as may be necessary from time to time during the term of this Agreement to replace or upgrade the replacement metering equipment specified in Section 9.4(a) above. Any such replacement metering equipment is to be owned, operated, and maintained by the Party installing such metering equipment. 9.5 Additional Metering Equipment In addition to the metering equipment installed pursuant to Section 9.4 above, each Party may at any time during the term of this Agreement install metering equipment; provided that, any such installation of such metering equipment shall not be inconsistent with permit provisions of Section 9.1 above. Any such metering equipment shall be owned, operated, and maintained by the Party installing such metering equipment. 9.6 Testing of Metering Equipment Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement, each Party during the term of this Agreement shall, at its expense, test its metering equipment associated with this Agreement at least once every two years, and, if requested by the other Party, shall make additional tests or inspections of such metering equipment, the expense of which shall be paid by such other Party unless such additional tests or inspections show the measurements of such metering equipment to be inaccurate. Each Party shall give reasonable notice of the time when any such test or inspection is to be made to the other Party who may have representatives present at such test or inspection. 9.7 Adjustments If any metering equipment fails to register, or if the measurement made by such metering equipment during a test made as provided above fails to meet the standards of such test, or if an error in meter reading occurs, adjustment shall be made correcting all measurements for the actual period during which such inaccurate measurements were made. Should any metering equipment at any time fail to register, or should registration thereof be so erratic as to be meaningless, the capacity, energy and reactive power delivered shall be determined from the best available data. If an estimate is required due to metering equipment malfunction, the method of estimating capacity, energy and reactive power delivered shall be made available and agreed upon by both Parties. Any metering equipment tested and found to be not more than one percent (1%) above or below normal shall be considered to be correct and accurate insofar as correction of billing is concerned. If any meter is found to be inaccurate by more than one percent (1%), then the Party owning such meter shall use its best efforts to adjust the meters immediately and accurately, and there shall be a retroactive adjustment of the inaccurate meter for the six (6)-month period prior to the test or inspection in which such inaccuracy is found. Any component of such installations found to be defective or inaccurate shall be adjusted, repaired, or replaced to provide accurate metering. 9.8 Billing Information BPA shall during the term of this Agreement transmit, or cause to be transmitted, or otherwise made available electronically to PSE the metered information of BPA's metering equipment, if any, (including kilowatt-hour and kilovar-hour) concerning electric power delivered under this Agreement. The metered information shall be transmitted or otherwise made available electronically in a format that is acceptable to PSE's billing function on a maximum time interval of one (1) hour or by mutual agreement to a longer time interval; such acceptance shall not be unreasonably withheld. With respect to currently installed and future replacement metering equipment, PSE will use good faith efforts to work with the owners of such metering equipment to develop a format that is acceptable to PSE, such acceptance shall not be unreasonably withheld. 9.9 Exchange of Metered Data The Party owning, operating, and maintaining each meter used to determine billing associated with the NITSA shall provide or arrange to be provided to the other Party all hourly meter readings and any more frequent load profile information, if existing, from each such meter. All meter reading information for a given month shall be validated and made available to the other Party in the succeeding month by 10:00 a.m. of the fifth (5th) working day of such succeeding month. All meter reading records and scheduled amounts shall be exchanged electronically between the Parties on a monthly basis. Either Party shall notify the other as soon as practicable in the event of system configuration changes or other events which may affect meter readings or access to meter reading information including, but not limited to, advance notice of planned line and substation outages and planned communications outages. 9.10 Use of BPA's Meter Reading Information Consistent with Section 9.9 above, BPA shall transmit, or cause to be transmitted, or otherwise made available electronically to PSE its real and reactive power metering data, if any, at the Point(s) of Delivery, and any other point that PSE reasonably deems appropriate for purposes of accounting for the transmission service provided under the NITSA, in a format compatible with the billing information systems used by PSE. 9.11 Metering and Communications Required for Integration of Network Resources BPA shall be responsible for all costs associated with the installation, operation and maintenance of any metering and communications equipment necessary for the integration of any generation resource to be designated an on-system Network Resource under the NITSA and on PSE's Transmission System. 9.12 Metering and Communications Required for Ancillary Services BPA shall be responsible for all costs associated with the installation, operation, and maintenance of any metering and communications equipment necessary for the provision of Ancillary Services by BPA or by a third party. All such metering and communication installations shall be installed, operated, and maintained pursuant to applicable NERC, WECC, and NWPP criteria and Good Utility Practice. 9.13 Installation and Use of PSE Meters Notwithstanding any other provision in this Section 9, PSE may at any time install metering equipment to make any measurements for any Point of Delivery required for any computation or determination mentioned in this Agreement or the NITSA. If such metering equipment is so installed, such measurements shall be used thereafter in such computation or determination; provided, that such metering equipment and calculation shall be subject to the accuracy standards described in Sections 9.6 and 9.7 above. 9.14 Real-Time Data Acquisition (a) Installation of real-time Telemetry equipment as described in the Facilities Study, if any, shall be performed by the Party identified in the Facilities Study to install such real-time Telemetry equipment. Any such real-time Telemetry equipment shall be owned, operated and maintained by the Party installing such equipment. (b) Each Party shall permit the other Party to install, or cause to be installed, real-time Telemetry equipment reasonably acceptable to PSE as may be necessary from time to time during the term of the NITSA to replace or upgrade the real-time Telemetry equipment specified in Section 9.14(a) above. Any such replacement real-time Telemetry equipment is to be owned, operated and maintained by the Party installing such equipment. 9.15 Real-Time Data Acquisition Upgrades The selection of any upgrades of real time Telemetry equipment and data, if any, from time to time during the term of this Agreement to be received by PSE and BPA shall be at the reasonable discretion of PSE, as deemed necessary for reliability, security, economics, and/or monitoring of Balancing Authority Area operations. This Telemetry includes, but is not limited to, loads, line flows, voltages, generator output, and breaker status of any of PSE's transmission facilities. To the extent Telemetry is required that is not available, BPA shall, at its own expense, install any metering equipment, data acquisition equipment, or other equipment and software necessary for the Telemetry to be received by PSE. Each Party shall be responsible for its cost of making any computer modifications or changes required to its own computer system(s) as necessary to implement this Section 9.15.

Section 8 Scheduling 8.1 Scheduling of Network Resources BPA's designated Network Resources(s) under the NITSA constitute(s) one or more contracts for the purchase by Kittitas from BPA of BPA system power. At such time as BPA intends to designate as a Network Resource under the NITSA a specific generation resource connected to PSE's Transmission System or to a third-party system as a Network Resource, this Agreement may be amended to provide applicable terms and conditions regarding the scheduling of such resource. 8.2 Scheduling of Contract Resources Schedules for BPA's designated contract Network Resources under the NITSA and schedules for BPA's secondary service pursuant to Section 28.4 of the Tariff shall be submitted to PSE in accordance with the Tariff. Hourly schedules shall be consistent with the Tariff and PSE's posted business practices. 8.3 Sharing of Schedule Information For purposes of operation of PSE's Balancing Authority Area and pursuant to 18 C.F.R. § 358.5(b), BPA consents to PSE's transmission function passing on BPA's hourly schedule under the NITSA to PSE's Balancing Authority function.

Section 11 Miscellaneous 11.1 Supremacy of Tariff In the event of any irreconcilable difference between the Tariff and this Agreement, the Tariff shall govern. 11.2 Notices Any formal notice to be served, given or made in connection with this Agreement shall be in writing and shall be directed as provided in the NITSA. Notices of an operating nature shall be given as provided in the NITSA. 11.3 Assignment PSE may assign this Agreement only upon the prior written consent of BPA, provided, however, that BPA hereby consents to the assignment of this Agreement to a successor of PSE that acquires all or substantially all of PSE's electric transmission assets. BPA and Kittitas may request an assignment of this Agreement from BPA to Kittitas. This assignment shall include all rights and post-assignment obligations associated with this Agreement. Such assignment shall require mutual agreement among PSE, BPA, and Kittitas; provided, that PSE shall not unreasonably withhold such agreement. When notice of such assignment is provided to PSE, BPA and Kittitas shall work in good faith to make any necessary modifications to this Agreement and the NITSA, implement metering modifications, ensure compliance with the Tariff, and make any other adjustments necessary to allow such assignment to proceed. If PSE withholds agreement to such assignment, PSE shall provide a detailed written explanation as to why it is withholding agreement and shall include a detailed list of items that would allow PSE to agree to such assignment. A Party requesting assignment shall provide at least six months' prior notice to the other Party. Any assignment pursuant to this Section 11.3 by an assignor to an assignee shall only be made with the contemporaneous assignment of the NITSA pursuant to Section 8.5 of the NITSA by the same assignor to the same assignee. Subject to the foregoing restrictions on assignment, this Agreement shall be binding upon, inure to the benefit of and be enforceable by the Parties and their respective successors and assigns. 11.4 Amendment; Exercise of Rights (a) This Agreement sets forth the sole and entire agreement between the Parties with respect to the subject matter hereof and may be amended only by written amendment accepted for filing by FERC. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Parties agree that nothing in this Agreement shall limit or otherwise affect any of the respective rights and obligations of the Parties pursuant to any other written agreement to which they are party, including, without limitation, any Remote Metering Access Agreement. (b) Nothing contained in the Tariff or this Agreement shall be construed as affecting in any way the right of PSE to unilaterally make application to FERC for a change in rates, terms and conditions, charges, classification of service, this Agreement, rule or regulation under Section 205 of the Federal Power Act and pursuant to FERC's rules and regulations promulgated thereunder. Nothing contained in the Tariff or this Agreement shall be construed as affecting in any way the ability of any Party receiving service under the Tariff to exercise its rights under the Federal Power Act and pursuant to FERC's rules and regulations promulgated thereunder. 11.5 Effect of Paragraph Headings Headings and captions appearing in this Agreement are inserted for convenience of reference only and shall not be construed to be interpretations of the text of this Agreement.

Section 10 Operation and Maintenance 10.1 Maintenance Scheduling and Continuity of Service PSE may require Curtailment or otherwise temporarily suspend service at the Point(s) of Delivery: (a) pursuant to Section 33 of the Tariff; and (b) without prior notice of such Curtailment or temporary suspension as may be necessary due to Force Majeure pursuant to Section 10 of the Tariff. Consistent with Section 33.7 of the Tariff, PSE shall use reasonable efforts to repair the cause of any such Curtailment or temporary suspension comparable to such reasonable efforts PSE uses with respect to its bundled retail Native Load Customers. 10.2 Emergency Planning and Operation As the Transmission Provider, PSE may undertake planning, coordinating, and implementing emergency operation schemes applicable to PSE's Transmission System. Examples of such schemes may include, but are not necessarily limited to, NWPP programs related to underfrequency load shedding, undervoltage load shedding and system restoration. Other schemes may be developed to meet NERC, WECC or NWPP reliability planning and operations objectives. BPA shall: (a) participate in the development and implementation of such load shedding and other programs to facilitate system reliability and security; (b) install and maintain or, in the alternative, require Kittitas to install and maintain, any required load shedding relays, including underfrequency and undervoltage relays; and (c) participate in system restoration planning.

Section 5 Interconnection Principles and Requirements PSE and BPA are parties to the Exchange Agreement (BPA Contract No 14-03-37050) providing for, among other things, the ownership, operation and maintenance of all or some of the Parties' interconnected electric facilities. Principles and requirements associated with the interconnection of the Parties' respective electric facilities shall be pursuant to the Exchange Agreement or its successor. If at any time PSE and BPA shall fail to be parties to the Exchange Agreement or its successor, PSE may amend this Agreement to be consistent with any successor interconnection arrangements between PSE and BPA's transmission function.

Section 4 Network Operating Committee 4.1 Membership The Network Operating Committee shall be composed of representatives from PSE, BPA and Kittitas. 4.2 Responsibilities The Network Operating Committee shall meet at least once per year to: (i) adopt rules and procedures consistent with this Agreement and the Tariff governing operating and technical requirements necessary for implementing Network Integration Transmission Service under the Tariff and NITSA; (ii) review designated Network Resources and Network Loads on an annual basis in order to assess the adequacy of the Transmission System, and (iii) obtain from PSE its operating policies, procedures, and guidelines for network interconnection and operation. 4.3 General Customer Information Requirement BPA shall, when requested by PSE, provide load forecasts, forecasts for generation by or for Kittitas (excluding power purchased from BPA), schedules and any other information (i) necessary for PSE's calculation of available transmission capability on PSE's Transmission System; (ii) necessary for PSE's implementation of redispatch, Curtailment, load shedding and congestion management procedures; (iii) necessary to enable PSE to operate its Transmission System adequately; or (iv) required to be provided by a Transmission Customer under the Tariff.

Section 7 Redispatch and Curtailment of Network Resources 7.1 Redispatch To Manage Transmission System Constraints In the event that PSE requires a redispatch of any designated Network Resource pursuant to Section 33.2 of the Tariff, such redispatch shall be undertaken pursuant to such Section 33.2 of the Tariff. The costs of redispatch shall be born by PSE and its Network Customers based upon a load ratio share methodology consistent with Section 33.3 of the Tariff. 7.2 Redispatch of Network Resources Connected to PSE's System. As of the Date of Agreement, BPA has no designated Network Resources connected to PSE's Transmission System. At such time as BPA intends to designate such a resource, PSE and BPA shall, subject to mutual agreement, specify applicable terms and conditions regarding the redispatch of such resource and PSE shall amend this section and this Agreement accordingly. 7.3 Redispatch of Network Resources Connected to Third-Party Systems BPA's designated Network Resource(s) under the NITSA constitute(s) one or more contracts for the purchase by Kittitas from BPA of BPA system power. At such time as BPA intends to designate a specific generation resource connected to a third-party system as a Network Resource under the NITSA, this Agreement may be amended to provide applicable terms and conditions regarding the redispatch of such resource. 7.4 Curtailment of Contract Resources Unless otherwise specified by PSE, designated contract Network Resources scheduled under the NITSA to PSE's system at a Point of Receipt shall not be available for redispatch. Pursuant to Sections 33.4 and 33.5 of the Tariff, PSE may require the Curtailment of scheduled deliveries from designated contract Network Resources under the NITSA at a specified Point of Receipt. In the event of such Curtailment, PSE shall, pursuant to Good Utility Practice and on a comparable basis with service to all other affected Network Customers and PSE's bundled retail Native Load Customers, accept scheduled deliveries up to an amount equal to the Curtailment at any other available Point of Receipt on PSE's system. Unless PSE directs BPA to incur additional transmission cost by providing specific instruction for scheduled deliveries of designated contract Network Resources to a specified alternate point of interconnection between PSE and BPA, any costs incurred by BPA to move its schedules to such other point of interconnection due to such Curtailment shall not be treated as redispatch cost. Any Energy Imbalances outside Deviation Band 1 (i.e., the narrowest band) that are incurred for the hour in which any such Curtailment is implemented and the next hour shall be settled as if such Energy Imbalances are within Deviation Band 1. If no alternate point of interconnection between PSE and BPA is available to BPA for the following hour or hours during such Curtailment, any resulting Energy Imbalances shall be settled as if they are within Deviation Band 1.

Section 6 Interconnection of Network Resources As of the Date of Agreement, BPA has no on-system designated Network Resources on PSE's Transmission System. At such time as BPA intends to designate such a resource, PSE and BPA shall, subject to mutual agreement, specify applicable principles and requirements for the interconnection of generation resources and shall amend this section and this Agreement accordingly.
